To access the [e-Chapters][4], go to the book forum e-Chapter section: User Name: bookreaders Password: Enter the first word on page 27 of the book.

paragraphs.text:
%md  
## Course Overview

[mooc outline, slides, video][1]
[1]: http://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~htlin/mooc/

%md
### What is Machine Learning
Learning: Acquiring skill from experience accumulated from observations.
Machine Learning: Acquiring skill with experience accumulated/computed from data.   

Skill: improve some performance measurement, e.g. predication accuracy.   

=> Machine Learning: improving some performance measure with experience computed from data.

result.msg:
What is Machine Learning

Learning: Acquiring skill from experience accumulated from observations.
Machine Learning: Acquiring skill with experience accumulated/computed from data.

Skill: improve some performance measurement, e.g. predication accuracy.

=> Machine Learning: improving some performance measure with experience computed from data.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### When ML?
* don't know how to define a solution, e.g. visual/speech recognition.
* human cannot program the system manually, e.g. we need to design a navigation system on Mars, but we do not know what kind of environment the rover will encounte.
* need rapid decision that requires large amount data analysis, and human just can not do it fast enough, e.g. stock market trading.
* need to create customer-targeted marketing for massive scale, e.g. recommendation engine.

result.msg:
When ML?

  • don't know how to define a solution, e.g. visual/speech recognition.
  • human cannot program the system manually, e.g. we need to design a navigation system on Mars, but we do not know what kind of environment the rover will encounte.
  • need rapid decision that requires large amount data analysis, and human just can not do it fast enough, e.g. stock market trading.
  • need to create customer-targeted marketing for massive scale, e.g. recommendation engine.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Applications of Machine Learning
* Food: 
    * data: get data feed from twitter or yalp about nearby resturant
    * skill: develop measurement of quality of food
* Clothing: 
    * data: get data of sales figures and survey
    * skill: give recommandation to client
* Housing:
    * data: characteristic of building and its energy energy use
    * skill: predict the energy usage of nearby building energy consumption
* Transportation
    * data: traffic signal images and traffic meanings
    * skill: recognize the traffic correctly
* Education
    * data: students' records on quizz of a online class
    * skill: predict a student whether be able to answer other quizzes correctly
* Entertainment
    * data: how other users rate a movie, for example, Netflix provided 100M rating from 480k user rated 17.7k movies.
    * skill: predict how a user rates a unrated movie, for example, to improve 10% recommendations.
    * solution: develop a user pattern: rating <- viewer/movie factors, movie can be describe as a chain of factors, we can multiple these two chains (matix).Since we only know rating,  we will ask the system to learn the movie factors from rating, and predict the user's unknown rating.

**ML is everywhere!!**

result.msg:
Applications of Machine Learning

  • Food:
    • data: get data feed from twitter or yalp about nearby resturant
    • skill: develop measurement of quality of food
  • Clothing:
    • data: get data of sales figures and survey
    • skill: give recommandation to client
  • Housing:
    • data: characteristic of building and its energy energy use
    • skill: predict the energy usage of nearby building energy consumption
  • Transportation
    • data: traffic signal images and traffic meanings
    • skill: recognize the traffic correctly
  • Education
    • data: students' records on quizz of a online class
    • skill: predict a student whether be able to answer other quizzes correctly
  • Entertainment
    • data: how other users rate a movie, for example, Netflix provided 100M rating from 480k user rated 17.7k movies.
    • skill: predict how a user rates a unrated movie, for example, to improve 10% recommendations.
    • solution: develop a user pattern: rating <- viewer/movie factors, movie can be describe as a chain of factors, we can multiple these two chains (matix).Since we only know rating, we will ask the system to learn the movie factors from rating, and predict the user's unknown rating.

ML is everywhere!!

paragraphs.text:
%md 
### Components of Machine Learning

#### problem: unknown target function, ***f***
* to find out the pattern for approving the credit card that benefit to a bank. A target function ***f***, which maps applicant ***X*** (information about different application) that leads to outcome of ***Y*** (different out comes).

#### training examples, ***D***
* input: information of each applicant, x: age, salary, exist debts,etc
* output: out come of each applicant, y: good or bad for bank/late payment/default
* collected data, ***D***: {(x1, y1), (x2, y2), ... (xn, yn)}

#### hypothesis set, ***H***
* There is a set of h in ***H***, we like to find a specific h, good skill, hopefully have good performance. We select the best h, we call it ***g***
* function ***g***, is part of H = {hk}, that can map ***X -> Y*** with good accuracy

#### learning algorithm, ***A***
* Use data to compute the best hypothesis, ***g***, which approximates to ***f***  

#### target fountion, ***g***  
* will be used to forecast future applicants.

### Learning Model
learning algorithm, ***A*** and hypothesis set, ***H***

result.msg:
Components of Machine Learning

problem: unknown target function, f

  • to find out the pattern for approving the credit card that benefit to a bank. A target function f, which maps applicant X (information about different application) that leads to outcome of Y (different out comes).

training examples, D

  • input: information of each applicant, x: age, salary, exist debts,etc
  • output: out come of each applicant, y: good or bad for bank/late payment/default
  • collected data, D: {(x1, y1), (x2, y2), … (xn, yn)}

hypothesis set, H

  • There is a set of h in H, we like to find a specific h, good skill, hopefully have good performance. We select the best h, we call it g
  • function g, is part of H = {hk}, that can map X -> Y with good accuracy

learning algorithm, A

  • Use data to compute the best hypothesis, g, which approximates to f

target fountion, g

  • will be used to forecast future applicants.

Learning Model

learning algorithm, A and hypothesis set, H

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Machine Learning and Other Fields

#### Data Mining (DM)
Difference between Data Mining and Machine Learning:
* Data Mining: Search thru huge amount of data to find interesting property or information.
* Machine Learning: Use data to compute hypothesis, g, that approximate to target function, f.
* DM is to find interesting property **same as**, or **related to**, or **help** hypothesis that approximate to target. 

**ML is very similar to DM.**

result.msg:
Machine Learning and Other Fields

Data Mining (DM)

Difference between Data Mining and Machine Learning:

  • Data Mining: Search thru huge amount of data to find interesting property or information.
  • Machine Learning: Use data to compute hypothesis, g, that approximate to target function, f.
  • DM is to find interesting property same as, or related to, or help hypothesis that approximate to target.

ML is very similar to DM.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Artificial Intelligent (AI)
* compute something that shows intelligent behavior

**ML can realize AI.**

result.msg:
Artificial Intelligent (AI)

  • compute something that shows intelligent behavior

ML can realize AI.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Statistic

* Statistics use data to make inference about unknown process
* Statistics focus on provable results with math assumptions.
   
**Statistic has many useful tools for ML.**

result.msg:
Statistic

  • Statistics use data to make inference about unknown process
  • Statistics focus on provable results with math assumptions.

Statistic has many useful tools for ML.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Learning to Answer Yes/No
### Perceptron Hypothesis Algorithm (PLA)
From [Wikipedia][1]:
Perceptron (感覺): a computer model or computerized machine devised to represent or simulate the ability of the brain to recognize and discriminate.  

**The perceptron is a linear classifier**, therefore it will never get to the state with all the input vectors classified correctly if the training set D is not linearly separable, i.e. if the positive examples can not be separated from the negative examples by a hyperplane. In this case, no "approximate" solution will be gradually approached under the standard learning algorithm, but instead learning will fail completely. Hence, if linear separability of the training set is not known a priori, one of the training variants below should be used.  

Variants:
* The Maxover algorithm (Wendemuth, 1995) is "robust" in the sense that it will converge regardless of (prior) knowledge of linear separability of the data set. In the linear separable case, it will solve the training problem - if desired, even with optimal stability (maximum margin between the classes)
* AdaTron uses the fact that the corresponding quadratic optimization problem is convex. The perceptron of optimal stability, together with the kernel trick, are the conceptual foundations of the support vector machine.
* The alpha-perceptron further used a pre-processing layer of fixed random weights, with thresholded output units. This enabled the perceptron to classify analogue patterns, by projecting them into a binary space. In fact, for a projection space of sufficiently high dimension, patterns can become linearly separable.
* ...

Other linear classification algorithms include 
* window,   
* support vector machine and   
* logistic regression.  
* pocket 

[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptron

result.msg:
Learning to Answer Yes/No

Perceptron Hypothesis Algorithm (PLA)

From Wikipedia:
Perceptron (感覺): a computer model or computerized machine devised to represent or simulate the ability of the brain to recognize and discriminate.

The perceptron is a linear classifier, therefore it will never get to the state with all the input vectors classified correctly if the training set D is not linearly separable, i.e. if the positive examples can not be separated from the negative examples by a hyperplane. In this case, no “approximate” solution will be gradually approached under the standard learning algorithm, but instead learning will fail completely. Hence, if linear separability of the training set is not known a priori, one of the training variants below should be used.

Variants:

  • The Maxover algorithm (Wendemuth, 1995) is “robust” in the sense that it will converge regardless of (prior) knowledge of linear separability of the data set. In the linear separable case, it will solve the training problem - if desired, even with optimal stability (maximum margin between the classes)
  • AdaTron uses the fact that the corresponding quadratic optimization problem is convex. The perceptron of optimal stability, together with the kernel trick, are the conceptual foundations of the support vector machine.
  • The alpha-perceptron further used a pre-processing layer of fixed random weights, with thresholded output units. This enabled the perceptron to classify analogue patterns, by projecting them into a binary space. In fact, for a projection space of sufficiently high dimension, patterns can become linearly separable.
  • …

Other linear classification algorithms include

  • window,
  • support vector machine and
  • logistic regression.
  • pocket

paragraphs.text:
%md
[perceptron vs gradient descent][1]
[Perceptron training rule, linear units, gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, delta rule][3]
Based on [perceptron vs gradient descent from coursera class][2] lecture, gradient descent is more general purpose. But SGD may reach different local optimization per initial values.

[1]: http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/137834/clarification-about-perceptron-rule-vs-gradient-descent-vs-stochastic-gradient
[2]: https://class.coursera.org/machlearning-001/lecture/279
[3]: http://euclid.nmu.edu/~mkowalcz/cs495f09/slides/lesson014.pdf

result.msg:
perceptron vs gradient descent
Perceptron training rule, linear units, gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, delta rule
Based on perceptron vs gradient descent from coursera class lecture, gradient descent is more general purpose. But SGD may reach different local optimization per initial values.
